Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Interacting disturbances: leaf to landscape dynamics of emerging disease, fire, and drought in California coastal forests
Award.AbstractNarration:
Over the past decade, millions of trees in California and Oregon forests have been attacked by an exotic pathogen, Phytophthora ramorum, causal agent of the infectious forest disease known as sudden oak death. This destructive outbreak is occurring in redwood and oak woodland communities in the same places that have also recently experienced devastating wildfires and extreme droughts. This research will use a novel combination of molecular, greenhouse, field, and computational modeling techniques to understand how disturbances created by wildfire, drought, and infectious disease interact and impact forest ecosystems. Results are expected to illuminate how wildfire affects the persistence and spread of an invasive pathogen, how biodiversity impacts emergence of disease in disturbed vs. undisturbed plant communities, and how these interacting disturbances alter nutrient cycling in forest ecosystems.

The combined research on the ecology of infectious disease, wildfire and drought will help develop best management practices for the growing number of forested landscapes around the world that are being impacted by complex, interacting disturbances. Outreach to stakeholders will be implemented through two highly effective organizations - University of California Cooperative Extension and the California Oak Mortality Task Force. The investigators will also be actively involved with advising state, federal and International regulatory committees put in place to create policy for managing sudden oak death and other forest diseases.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In the past year, we have focused our activities in several distinct areas:

 

1-    Analysis of repeated sampling data obtained through the citizen science program called SOD-Blitzes.

2-    Establishment of plots to study the drought ecology of Sudden Oak Death and to design disease management strategies, by performing stand manipulations

3-    Analyses using complex statistical and geostatistical approaches of a large dataset to investigate the ecology of infection between the most transmissive host of Sudden Oak Death, California bay laurel, and the dead end host, California Coast live oak

4-    We finalized our analysis of the dynamics of infection in dry and wet periods in a network of plots in the San Francisco peninsula.  We are using multi-variate, analysis to see how disease incidence on bay laurels may be correlated to ecological conditions including, temperature, precipitation, canopy cover, aspect, bay density, bay basal area, and oak infection

5-    We have continued to run a large citizen science program and have improved our outreach .

6-    We have created two new major extension/outreach tools. A) Nature Tour is an app that allows English-speaking and Spanish-speaking people to visit and understand the biology, history and ongoing research in a State Forest. B) Calinvasive: this is a major innovative tool that has been spearheaded by my group with the collaboration and support of Calflora. It is a database management system that will be fully interfaced with the Calflora database and will allow stakeholders to access biological, ecological, epidemiological, distribution and control information about emergent microbial and insect threats to native California ecosystems

 

 

 

RESULTS

 

1-           During the last two blitzes we surveyed over 23.000 trees and processed 20.000 samples from 4000 symptomatic trees. The survey covered most of the range of SOD.  Over 1000 people attended the 2015/2016 blitzes.  The data are presented in two Google Earth maps (the SOD Blitz map available at www.sodblitz.org and the SOD map available at www.sodmap.org) but are also uploaded on the SODmap mobile Apps, where the information is used to determine the risk for oak infection at any given location in California.

2-  We are interested in the distribution of trees that act as reservoirs and superspreaders of SOD.  In order to better address the issue of distribution of trees that play a key epidemiological role in the spread and resilience of SOD we designed a different set of plots, where contiguous trees would be sampled. A total of 30 circular plots with a 30 m radius containing at least 25 bay laurel trees were laid out and sampled. We also used those data to identify eight plots where a stand manipulation study (bay removal) could be started (see below).

3-           In plant pathosystems in which some hosts are transmissive and some are dead-ends, infection is mediated by multiple factors including the susceptiblity of both hosts, the sporulation potential of transmissive hosts, the mobility of infectious propagules, the presence of environmental factors conducive to infection, and the variability in distribution of both host types. Here we report, for the first time, on inoculum levels necessary for SOD to successfully infect adult oaks, and on the distribution of such inoculum levels through time and space thanks to a 7-year long monitoring effort across a network of 128 monitoring points.

4-           The application of epidemiological models can play an important role in understanding disease progression and in determining the most effective strategies for disease control. Heterogeneity in transmission among individuals, spatial regions, and years complicates efforts to predict disease outbreaks. However, predicting and targeting important spatial or temporal hotspots, and individual superspreading or refugial hosts, could lead to substantial gains in efficiency and reductions in costs of control efforts.

5-           The SOD Blitz citizen science program has been successful and received considerable attention by the media, including being recently cited as a model for conveying scientific discoveries to the public in the Science section of the NY times and being cited as a way to promote action by the Washington post in June 2016. Some of the recent major improvements to the program include: a) Blitzes designed for native people, b)-Blitzes for kids, c)-Videos to remind participants on how to survey, on how to interpret the data, and on what to do about SOD.

6-           We have used our outreach/extension experience on SOD to broaden our reach beyond SOD. One App we developed has the goal of showcasing the importance of natural ecosystems and the research that helps maintaining them functional. In June 2016 we launched the App called Nature Tour to do that (both in English and Spanish to attract a larger share of constituents). See www.naturetour.org.  At a different level is our collaboration with Calflora to create a database management system to include all key information about invasive pests and pathogens.

           http://www.calflora.org/entry/calpsearch.html (search Phytophthora, Polyphagous, Geosmithia, Heterobasidion)
